entry.title: Information Overload 2010-12-26
entry.content:
• "The Limits of Pain - Irukandji Syndrome":http://godheadv.blogspot.com/2010/12/limits-of-pain-irukandji-syndrome.html
    Small jellyfish, big pain!
  • "The Simple Software That Could -- but Probably Won't -- Change the Face of Writing":http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2010/12/the-simple-software-that-could-but-probably-wont-change-the-face-of-writing/68364/
    "T.S. Eliot":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._S._Eliot and "Etherpad":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etherpad aren't often mentioned int the same article, but here they are.
  • "How I Made Money Spamming Twitter with Contextual Book Suggestions":http://www.charleshooper.net/blog/how-i-made-money-spamming-twitter-with-contextual-book-suggestions/
    The fine line between spam and a useful service.
  • "The Blast Shack":http://www.webstock.org.nz/blog/2010/the-blast-shack/
    If you only want to read one article on Wikileaks, make it this one by Bruce Stirling!
  • "Getting shot by a handgun":http://tidypub.org/ldcUR
    A person describing what it was like to be shot in the chest.
  • "Das Welthemd":http://www.zeit.de/2010/51/Billige-T-Shirts
    German weekly "Die Zeit":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_Zeit uses an H&M T-Shirt to explain how the globalized economy works. Follow the story through the US, Bangladesh and Malaysia to Germany (in German).
  • "Censorship - Won't someone think of the adults?":http://gonedigital.net/2010/12/20/censorship-%E2%80%93-won%E2%80%99t-someone-think-of-the-adults/
    Next time someone goes "Think of the children!" on you, you'll know what to say.
  • "Solving the Expression Problem with Clojure 1.2":https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/library/j-clojure-protocols/
    Great writeup by Stuart Halloway on how Clojure protocols help in solving the "Expression Problem":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expression_Problem.
  • "Shigeru Miyamoto, Nintendo's man behind Mario":http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/12/20/101220fa_fact_paumgarten?currentPage=all
    Awesome article on "Shigeru Miyamoto":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shigeru_Miyamoto, most awesome video game designer ever.
  • "Signal, Curation, Discovery":http://battellemedia.com/archives/2010/12/signal_curation_discovery
    Thougths on searching the web.

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-12-05
entry.content:
• "Die unertraegliche Lameness des Web 2.0":http://blog.koehntopp.de/archives/2978-Die-unertraegliche-Lameness-des-Web-2.0.html
    Why the "social web" fails and what could be done better. I couldn't agree more, the author tackles lots of valid points (in German, but also "available in English":http://blog.koehntopp.de/archives/2978-Die-unertraegliche-Lameness-des-Web-2.0.html#en. Update: Currently offline because of the controversial "JMStV":http://www.techeye.net/internet/web-age-certificates-law-forces-german-blogs-offline).
  • "What Your Computer Does While You Wait":http://duartes.org/gustavo/blog/post/what-your-computer-does-while-you-wait
    Interesting article comparing the relative speeds of the various parts in your computer, using illustrative examples.
  • What's New in Ruby 1.9.2
    I've been using 1.9 since it came out, and 1.9.2 definitely is the best Ruby I've ever used. Hopefully this post by Dave Thomas will convince even more people to finally leave 1.8 behind.
  • "The Xenotext Experiment":http://www.law.ed.ac.uk/ahrc/script-ed/vol5-2/editorial.asp#sdendnote2sym
    Awesome beyond words, the Xenotext Experiment tries to combine genetics and poetry.
  • "Full Body Scanners: What's Next?":http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2010/12/full_body_scann.html
    Bruce Schneier, spot on as always.
  • "Favelas, Drug Trade & Twitter: What Went Down in Rio":http://www.aspiringluminary.com/post/1726856462
    The role of mobile phones and Twitter in the recent "favela wars" in Rio.
  • "Google Maps & Label Readability":http://www.41latitude.com/post/2072504768/google-maps-label-readability
    Interesting read on what little tricks Google uses to make their maps more readable than their competitors'.
  • "Spacelog":http://spacelog.org/
    Transcripts of early space exploration missions, beautifully visualized.
  • "Mercury poisoning makes male birds homosexual":http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn19784-mercury-poisoning-makes-male-birds-homosexual.html
    As interesting as this is scientifically, I'm already afraid of all the nuts who'll try to extrapolate these results to humans.
  • "Conflict or Cooperation?":http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/66802/richard-k-betts/conflict-or-cooperation?page=show
    Good comparison of the theories of Fukuyama, Mearsheimer and Huntington.
